Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: The Role of Disorder in an Expanded Family of Nitride Semiconductors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description: The binary nitride semiconductors (gallium nitride, aluminum nitride, and indium nitride) and their alloys have found commercial applications in optoelectronics and high-power electronics. However, their applications are limited by materials constraints. In particular, gallium and indium are expensive, and indium is scarce. The research activities here center around the idea of replacing the valence 3 element gallium or indium by equal proportions of valence 2 and valence 4 elements, such as, for example, zinc and tin, or magnesium and silicon, all of which are less expensive and more abundant. In addition, these new ternary semiconductors are expected to have unique properties that will make possible new, important applications. The educational activities of this project include the recruiting and training of graduate and undergraduate students, and the involvement of local area high-school teachers in professional development and in the design and development of high-school science curricula.

Technical Description: The research focuses on the synthesis of the zinc- and magnesium-containing ternary nitrides using vapor-liquid-solid methods. The primary objectives include the elucidation of the roles of defects and disorder on the optical properties, the development of new growth techniques, and the development of understanding of the thermodynamic properties. Temperature-dependent steady-state and time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy and photoluminescence excitation spectroscopy provide insight into the band structure, defect properties, and carrier relaxation and recombination processes. The development of the ternary nitride semiconductors provides a transformative potential that would extend the capabilities of the binary nitrides, which could not only overcome some of the lingering problems of the latter materials, in particular extending the accessible wavelength range for light emitters further into the ultraviolet and through the entire visible spectrum, but also lead to entirely new applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The binary nitride semiconductors indium nitride, gallium nitride and aluminum nitride have enabled the revolution in lighting technology by their application to light emitting diodes, which save almost an order of magnitude in power compared to incandescent lighting. This family of semiconductors is also central to a similar ongoing revolution in power electronics. The heterovalent ternary nitride semiconductors, for example zinc germanium nitride, are closely related to the binary nitrides but there has been relatively much less research done on their synthesis and properties. Yet, this more complex and much larger family of materials holds promise for extending important properties of the binary nitrides, for example in their combination with the binaries to make efficient green and yellow light emitting diodes, and in their use for efficient solar cells composed entirely of cheap, abundant and nontoxic elements.

In this project we developed a novel vapor-liquid-solid method for growing these materials. We grew high quality zinc tin nitride and zinc germanium nitride. We measured their optical and structural properties using scanning electron microscopy, Raman scattering, x-ray diffraction spectroscopy and photoluminescence spectroscopy. We showed theoretically that the atomic arrangements in the ternary nitride semiconductors can include two different phases, and that in some cases these two phases can be of similar energies and thus it is thermodynamically favorable for both to be present, while in other cases their energies are sufficiently different that it is thermodynamically favorable for the material to be single phase. We showed, in an example of the latter situation (for zinc germanium nitride) that growing the material at sufficiently high temperature produces single phase material, while growing material at lower temperatures produces material that is either a combination of the two phases, or, more likely, produces material with many "exchange defects"; that is, zinc atoms on what should be germanium lattice sites, and vice versa. In addition, we showed if we take material grown at lower temperatures and anneal it at the higher temperature, we can transform that material to single phase. On the other hand, if the two phases have sufficiently close energies, as predicted for zinc tin nitride, then it should not be possible to produce single phase material.  Further exploration of these questions, and application of these models to a broader complement of this family of semiconductors, is critical for determining their optical and electronic properties and, consequently, their potential applications to the development of new technologies. Our results from this project are documented in two Ph.D. theses, five published journal articles and, at the time of this writing, a sixth journal article in review.

Broader impacts of this ongoing research include the potential to impact technology to make better, more efficient, less toxic optoelectronic devices including light emitting diodes operating in wavelength ranges for which they are currently inefficient, and to make solar cells from cheap, nontoxic and abundant materials. Broader impacts of this project also included training two graduate students, who finished their Ph.D. research with the support of this grant, and the participation of six undergraduate students, including one underrepresented minority student, in the research. In addition, a high school physics teacher from the Cleveland public school system was supported for three summers to develop new educational materials for his students, most of whom are minority students. The focus chosen by this teacher was to develop experiments and demonstrations to make "real world" connections to the science?to help make it come alive to them. Among the projects explored were solar cells, a cloud chamber that imaged cosmic ray tracks, and student projects to in-class design, construction and testing of catapults. In summary, the teacher reported that "My experimentation often motivated my students to experiment with their own ideas about similar topics. Not only did they teach me new things, but they would also help educate their fellow students."
